Inferência Variacional na moral, parte 1

Motivação e intuição

\[ \newcommand{\V}[1]{{\bf #1}} \newcommand{\Vg}[1]{\boldsymbol{#1}} \]

Introdução

Este conjunto de notas está no plano das ideias há bastante tempo, mais ou menos desde quando comecei a me aventurar no reino da Inferência Variacional (doravante IV), lá pelos anos de 2019, junto com meu grande amigo Carlos Tadeu. Resumidamente, IV é uma ferramenta para realizar inferência aproximada em modelos estatísticos demasiadamente complexos de modo que algoritmos de Monte Carlo baseados em cadeias de Markov (MCMC - Markov Chain Monte Carlo) são extremamente custosos computacionalmente, chegando possivelmente a serem inviáveis. Nos últimos anos, técnicas de IV estão cada vez mais difundidas na literatura estatística, e é justamente aí que nasce minha motivação para essas notas: por mais que tenhamos excelentes textos sobre o tema (veja por exemplo Hoffman et al. (2013), Kucukelbir et al. (2017), Blei, Kucukelbir, and McAuliffe (2017))

is a tool for performing approximate inference on complex statistical models that is being even more widespread within the Statistics community, as well as in its applications. However, there is a lack in the literature for a comprehensive introduction to VI, including a background on Information Theory. This set of notes aim to fill this gap, as well as present an extensive (but potentially not exhaustive) overview of VI.

Motivation

In order to motivate the need of VI, let us present a brief example.

Example 1 (Motivation for VI) Assume that we have a set of observations \(\V{x} = (x_1, \dots, x_n)\) that is known to come from a mixture of \(K\) Gaussian distributions, wich respective means \(\Vg{\mu} = (\mu_1, \dots, \mu_K)\) and common variance equal to 1. Several inference tasks could be of interest, e.g., estimating the means \(\Vg{\mu}\) or computing the marginal likelihood (also called the evidence) \(p(\V{x})\). For this, in a Bayesian setting we specify prior distributions as in the following generative model:

  • The mean parameters are drawn from the same distribution \(p(\mu_k)\), assumed to be a Gaussian \(N(\mu_k | 0, \sigma^2)\), being \(\sigma^2\) a hyperparameter;

  • For each observation \(x_i\) choose a cluster assignment, that is, a vector \(\V{c}_i\) which consists of zeros except for a one in the position corresponding to the respective cluster;

  • Finally, sample the value of \(x_i\) from the distribution \(N(x_i | \V{c}_i^T \Vg{\mu} , 1)\).

More precisely, we have that: \[ \begin{equation} \begin{split} x_i | \V{c}_i, \Vg{\mu} &\sim N(x_i | \V{c}_i^T \Vg{\mu} , 1), i = 1, \dots, n, \\ \V{c}_i &\sim \text{Categorical}(1/K, \dots, 1/K), i = 1, \dots, n, \\ \mu_k &\sim N(\mu_k | 0, \sigma^2), k = 1, \dots, K, \end{split} \end{equation} \]

The joint distribution can be written as: \[ \begin{equation} \begin{split} p(\V{x}, \Vg{\mu}, \V{c}_1, \dots, \V{c}_n) &= p(\Vg{\mu})p(\V{c}_1, \dots, \V{c}_n)p(\V{x} | \V{c}_1, \dots, \V{c}_n, \Vg{\mu}) \\ &= p(\Vg{\mu}) \prod_{i = 1}^{n} p(\V{c}_i)p(\V{x}_i | \V{c}_i, \Vg{\mu}) \end{split} \end{equation} \]

So, more generally, we have a probability distribution \(p(\Vg{\theta})\) from which we desire to extract information. If this distribution is sufficiently complicated, usual techniques like MCMC may fail to provide an answer in a reasonable time. It becomes reasonable to \(p(\Vg{\theta})\) by a simpler distribution \(q(\Vg{\theta})\), from which inference is more feasible, worthing the drawback of not performing inference on the desired distribution. There are two important questions to aks ourselves:

  1. How to measure the distance between probability distributions?

  2. How to obtain distribution \(q(\Vg{\theta})\)?

In the literature there are several proposed methods to perform both tasks, but here we will focus on one choice of distance between distributions, the , which leads to the technique known as . This is a quantity inspired by the Information Theory, from which a brief overview will be presented. With regard to the obtention of the approximating distribution, several methods will be discussed.

References

Blei, David M., Alp Kucukelbir, and Jon D. McAuliffe. 2017. “Variational Inference: A Review for Statisticians.” Journal of the American Statistical Association 112 (518).
Hoffman, Matthew D., David M. Blei, Chong Wang, and John Paisley. 2013. “Stochastic Variational Inference.” Journal of Machine Learning Research 14 (40).
Kucukelbir, Alp, Dustin Tran, Rajesh Ranganath, Andrew Gelman, and David M. Blei. 2017. “Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference.” Journal of Machine Learning Research 18 (1).
